content.rendered: Happy Birthday Bruce! Have an amazing day. Thank you for being you!
Sounds so good. I was at the concert, too.
My first Bruce Springsteen concert 40 years ago today Sept 18,1985

Regarding the last
“Well I guess everything dies baby that’s a fact
But maybe everything that dies someday comes back”
I see it as, given what the last verse is about, the ghosts of the past coming back to haunt you.
There’s just so many ways to interpret those lyrics.
Listen to Martin Simpsons version- beautiful
At the 2003 Chapel Hill show, Bruce opened with “I Walk the Line” in memory of Johnny Cash, who had just passed away a few days before
That is some fantastic audience-shot footage (Stone Pony, 9.14) with fantastic audio! (New entry: 2024)
That is some great audience shot footage (Stone Pony, 9.14) with fantastic audio. (New entry, 2024)

I’ve always that that the first line reflects how shocked Bruce felt what Steve told him he was leaving the band. It was such a surpise it would have felt like showing up at your friends house only to find out they left without telling you.
Candy is a hooker, no doubt, but he’s not a client because (i) they kiss (ii) he sees the darkness behind her eyes and (iii) they go driving together.

“Springsteen…from the moment he walks on stage with his superb E Street band, his impact is impossible to ignore. His energy seems almost unbounded…a wildly feral and a wholehearted friendly approach.” (9.6.78 Uptown Theater show review)

I was there that night! It was me and my ma’s first time being able to see them live, as well. It’s one of my favorite moments from the show, as it was the first time the band played that song in my entire life (Sept. ‘88 birth). My ma’s was the 2 brothers on stage for “No Surrender”
Inferior vocalist, lyricist…
I hope roll of the dice comes back, it seemed like it was a lot of work but the out cone was some great writing and some really interesting reads.
I was there on the rails with my oldest daughter. It was magical. My second favorite of all the Bruce shows I’ve seen. (The first being sea hear now in Asbury Park!)
My god… the foreshadowing… you are brilliant.
Fixed it, thanks!
Thank you!

“The the lyrics kick in, and the scene is set at a topless bar

TheN the lyrics…

Fabulous post Ken, it does what the best music writing does – make you curious and excited to experience the song. Coming to LNITP as it’s released on Tracks III, it’s made me laugh out loud. It really captures the joy and humour that Bruce does like no one else. Thank you!

Ken, I agree 100 per cent with you. So many of Bruce’s throw away pieces (i.e., Detail Man) are heart throbbing gems—all the sexual innuendo but packaged brilliantly! Better than many of his pop favorites in my book.

My favorite song on Nebraska…until I saw Bruce & The E Street Band do a full out rock version in 2024 in Philadelphia!! Fell in love all over again!! You need to change your data for “last performed” 😉

I enjoy seeing how Springsteen’s lyrics evolve. You can tell that he’s very much a writer who believes in saying as much as possible with as few words as possible, and an editor who believes in cutting. The Devil and God become a vague ‘they,’ and fire becomes implicit, with the paranoia becoming stronger as a result.

Your website has been a godsend to read through, I’m finding new appreciation for even my absolute favorite Springsteen songs with every article I read.

I was there that night. I have heard stories that Max Weinberg barely made it on stage after suffering some sort of bad back troubles. It was a spectacular show on a gorgeous night. Across the Border was perfect. And Ramrod shook the place, with Bruce playfully announcing the Big Man’s dance moves.
Ken, I hit a paywall when I try to access the “retrospective” for the 1970 7th and Marshall Steel Mill set. Is there a way to by pass it? Thanks.
Are there ever going to be any more Rolls of the Dice?

On this day in 2005, Bruce Springsteen solo at the Fox Theater, St Louis on the ‘Devils & Dust’ tour:

Amidst much cheering, Bruce walked onstage about 8:15. The Fox Theater was sold out, all 4,000 seats filled. Easily the most ornate theater I had ever been in, just a beautiful setting, every square inch decorated. I was maybe 15 feet from the microphone, prime seating to be sure. The stage was framed in plush red velvet drapes, 2 chandeliers overhead.

Dressed in blue jeans, a black shirt rolled up above his elbows and boots, Bruce looked fit and happy. Despite the grind of being on the road for months at a time, it appeared that performing live agreed with him.

He sat at the keyboard and opened with a rarity ‘Back in Your Arms’, then took out his harmonica and played ‘Reason to Believe’ in a funky, smoky delta blues style, keeping time with his boot pounding the stage. As he finished that, he strapped on his acoustic guitar and went right into ‘Devils & Dust’, the title track from his latest release. It was about this time that I felt the sides of my face hurting, and I realized it was from grinning non-stop!

Bruce continued to entertain us for the next two and a half hours, featuring songs from his new album and a mix of some of his older classics. He played piano, electric piano, harmonica, acoustic 6 and 12 string guitars and for a memorable performance of ‘Part Man, Part Monkey’ plugged in an electric guitar.

He was in a good mood, chatting with the crowd, sharing stories of his growing up, being raised Catholic, the trials and tribulations of being a parent of a teenager.

Early on he played ‘County Fair’, a perfect song for late summer. However, he botched one of the lines, stopped, went back to play it again and messed it up again. He laughed and said “Okay, how about I just skip that line”!

He played ‘The River’ on piano, then brought the house to its feet with a standing ovation for the first ever solo performance of ‘Backstreets’! As the crowd stood and cheered at the conclusion, Bruce stood up from the piano, put on his guitar, strode to the microphone while a floor level flood light came on behind him, framing him in the brightness. He then sang the opening lines “Can’t see nothin’ in front of me, can’t see nothin’ comin’ up behind” from ‘The Rising’. Lots of emotion in that song, played superbly.

The whole night was like that, just one amazing song after another with nary a break.
He finished up, waved to the crowd and walked offstage to deafening applause and cheers. A few minutes later he walked back out for a 5-song encore while the entire crowd stood. One of the songs was the classic ‘The Promised Land’ but played in an entirely different style. Bruce strummed the chords, then used his thumb and fingers to keep a percussive beat going against the body of the acoustic guitar, hard to describe but done in a great way.

He finished off the night with a cover of the song ‘Dream Baby Dream’, played on pump organ. He got the organ to play on a loop, stood up and walked to the front of the stage and sang while the organ played behind him. Holding a microphone in one hand, waving the other hand back and forth in a mesmerizing rhythm, he swayed back and forth as he sang. He finished the song and walked offstage as the organ continued to play, a very satisfying finish.

When the house lights came up and the fans gave one final round of thunderous applause before heading out, I thought the night could not have been any better. We stood and talked while waiting for the crowd to thin out, the aisles were jammed. I turned and looked back into the wings of the stage and saw Bruce standing by himself, arms folded. I waved at him and he waved back, the perfect ending to a perfect night!
“Rosalita” (12:33) and “Prove It All Night” (9:45) from the Louisville Gardens (1978) sure sound like high-gen soundboards. Fun stuff!
Still the 75 version in New York to this day
Pienso lo mismo que el dueño de este post sobre la canción. No me parece romántica ni amorosa en ningún punto. Pero la amo.
Ronnie had a beautiful voice and was very pretty. Both her and her sister taken to early.
Thanks! I fixed it.

The correct title to the Steel Mill Song is “Sherlock Goes HOME”, not ‘Holmes’.
Supporting proof cane be found here,

“SPL Uber Visual Historical Artifacts. Pre-Greetings Manuscripts Vol. 7: Early Set Lists”

where a photocopy of an era set list (proposed) is shown to have the tittle written twice in Bruce’s handwriting. There is clearly no ‘l’ or ‘s’.

You have to have a better video than what is posted (1988 Munich)
I’m sure not many fans want to watch this version (better shots of the back of people’s hands than of Bruce). No one wants to hear people in the audience having a conversation while Bruce is on stage.

7.10.19–Bruce calls into E Street Radio from his car.
D. Marsh: “It’s great to hear from you. You don’t have like 5 more albums and another movie up your
sleeve do you?”
Bruce: “Actually, I do.”
Everyone: (laughs)

I was there that night!
I have a picture with Bruce in the afternoon of that woinderfull day!
And Bruce invited us to come to the Stone Pony to se the concert!

I just discovered this listening to a recent live band performance. They kill it!!! Sure it’s great to hear the original demo on piano but he raises the key and it gives it more urgency. Surprised they put out an old song like this but I love the fact that he’s loosening it up a little….Now just mix up the setlist a bit more please?
Is it just me or does the harmonica seem reminiscent of she’s the one? I feel like there could be some symbolism there

Yes Fugitives Dream and Unsatisfied Heart wow. Brilliant analysis.
Just a thought re the “thing he’d done” could it have been a secret, past homosexual relationship between the 2 men? Why did he touch his cheek, if he was going to kill him? Was it still a yearning for what they had… Was there A blackmail angle from the stranger re sex? Just a thought. Thanks again, Gareth
Bad Moon Rising in Paris is great!
Great interview with Patti!
It appears like Bruce has 6 fingers on his left hand at the stone pony show. Does anyone else see this?

It would be a big ask to get Bruce to cover Love and Mercy during one of his upcoming shows – as a tribute to Brian. For me this would be an emotional melding of two of my musical heroes. Go for it Boss – two masters creating one three minute nirvana.

I submitted a review of the Cardiff Magic show to Backstreets and they emailed me back saying “Pete, check out brucespringsteen.net!” My review was right there, on Bruce’s official site! I was beyond stoked!
A little while later I saw my review was used in the liner notes of the bootleg from the show!

New for 2025: review for 1978/ Nice review of the Omaha show on this date: “Everyone had been standing since the end of the first encore…though the house lights, which usually indicate the show is over, came on to stay at that point.”
Open the second show in Stockholm 2024.

Stumbled across this historical post now in 2025. Curious what the author thinks about the Manchester version just released. I can’t stop listening. Also wondering given the June 2025 state of affairs in California, what the author’s thoughts are on the cut out verse.
It was an incredible night. Most of the crowd left early because it was raining heavily all night and then Bruce came out. It was an incredible feeling of joy and electricity.

How beautifully poetic, and very Bruceian (which is a word I just made up but I think fits) that American Skin (41 Shots) was debuted on the anniversary of the release of Born In The USA.
If they didn’t get the message the first time, he gave it to them again.
I’ll never forget downloading the song on Napster.

Thanks Ken, this is really beautiful and moving.

I have posted it to my brother in law.

Jamie, what do you think?

Xxx

I “vote”, per the Brucebase discussion, that the above live take of “Rosalita” is more likely to have been from Max’s Kansas City” in January, 1973 versus the “agreed upon date” of 6.6.73 in Philadelphia when opening for Chicago. The enthusiastic crowd response at the end sure sounds like a small club to me.

When Bruce reaches for the soaring vocals, right where he begins to come down from the very highest note, he sings a few notes that remind me of the opening to Ragdoll by Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons. I love both versions of this song.

In this video about Diane “Rosalita” Lozito, she implies that Bobby Jean was written about her breakup with Bruce. It makes me wonder if he wrote an early version of the song about that and didn’t do anything with it, but then pulled it back up and reworked/completed it to express his sadness about Steve. I’ve heard it said more than once that losing a band mate is not so different from losing a lover. I love that you wrote about Clarence’s final note – it always, always makes me tear up. https://youtu.be/aZLcopkA5Ds?si=5dxXk7nrDNgHHo_Z
Thank you 💜 my world is better bc your blog is in it.

FYI: The Barcelona concert (2023) had Tom Hanks and Rita Wilson in attendance. 🙂

New for 2025: New entry for 2017: Ken, That is some FANTASTIC audience-shot footage. (I count at least three cameras w/ soundboard audio. Wow!) Good find. Just one more reason to (still) believe in The E Shuffle and Kingdom of Days.
Harry was a real guy. He was a mutual friend of my girlfriend and Bruce. The story about Harry is too long to detail here.
That’s so funny, I always heard it as “going down to where the sins turn into gold” either way it’s an incredible line.

One potential hole in the 9/11 connection; In the posted 2003 performance, he uses the OLD “something that ain’t there no more” lyric! That said, I am willing to acknowledge the Rising/9-11-tribute sentiment had dissipated a bit by 2003, and perhaps he just reverted back or followed a lyric sheet that night.
Regardless, a beautiful and insightful interpretation of the work – thank you, John.
Now just days away!
Just today was released “Repo Man” and if these two aren’t one and the same in origin I’ll be extremely surprised.

See I’ve read this song as a sort an epilogue to racing in the street, especially considering the four corners approach which would match up the 2. He and his baby (I’ve always read that as his baby is the car as the girl has no defined sins in the song but that’s a conversation for another day) drive to the sea and wash the sins away. But they don’t stay away. He goes back to street racing and she still doesn’t approve (still racing out in the tressles, but that blood never burned in her veins). She eventually leaves him because of this and sharpens up much to his chagrin while he’s still racing (well if you want to see… I’m easily found… there’s a spot neath Adam’s bridge) and reminiscent of the scene from grease he’s still racing just this time under the bridge. Like you say he’s addicted but I’d argue it’s to racing rather than drugs as he seems to use it to clear his mind of the darkness on the edge of town, aka his depression.

New for 2025: video for 2000; audio for 2000: My favorite E Street LOHAD has always been the ’99-’00 Reunion’s version–jangling guitars, Garry’s bass, Steven’s ukulele, Bruce’s deep, passionate singing and more. Love the I.E.M. on the videos and on the “Leavin’ Train” soundcheck. Wow. Thanks, Ken.
Another hidden gem by Bruce!

Ken, Do you know who wrote the positive review for Bruce’s 1973 Ahmanson Theater/Los Angeles C.B.S. promotion appearance? Commenting on Bruce’s first album release, the journalist writes, “{A} promising new artist…he is, for me, more exciting for the potential his current work suggests than for that actual work, a rich, but sometimes diffused series of musical collages..” (Could the author be the L.A. Times’ Robert Hilburn?) P.S.–Love the pro-shot “Joe Hill” from Tampa on this important day.
Like Set Lusting Bruce, this was MY first Springsteen concert, too! Seeing my fellow Texan join Bruce for this tune was a special treat.
That “Get off from work” verse is so similar to the first verse of “Jackson Cage.” I think there’s (at least) one other of his songs that contains similar lines but can’t recall which one.
Ken, I’m glad you highlighted and included the full audio of “Mr. Tambourine Man”. Beyond classic.

2009 Boston “ Sedated” show and Marriage Proposal by Dropkicks Tim Brennan those we’re two outstanding shows. Was lucky enough to be in the PIT both nights one w/a great pull on lottery.
High energy and a looseness that I hope comes back having seen 3 shows in 23/24. Well actually I hope ESB comes back to US in 25 or 26
New for 2024: Ken, Nice Columbus video shoot (3:03:41); full show, single camera, completely steady w/out head instruction. Good find. Feels like you’re there.

From the Johnson City Press Chronicle (4.20.76): “Although the crowd at Freedom Hall numbered less than a thousand, Bruce Springsteen came to play.” My friend, Scott S., who was then a student at
U of T agrees. Scott loved the show and was able to move to stage-front. He remembers, as Bruce, with back to the audience, slammed the set opener (“Night”) shut while all house lights go black! An intense and transforming moment that has stayed with Scott.
No April 19th KOD???? No email yesterday. ?????

This song always brings me to tears. Such a lovely testament to their love for each other. This performance is unbelievably great, from Patti’s gorgeous vocals to Bruce’s simple yet amazing guitar solo. It doesn’t get much better.

Love this image from Dan Conner’s review of Bruce singing “Tenth Avenue” at U of Rochester’s Palesta, on this date in 1976–“The lighting cues…isolating Springsteen in a single white spot as he sang the line ‘I’m all alone, I’m all alone’.” We all wish we were there.

I like the comment about the 1984 performance matching the week BITUSA hit #1. The performance on August 5th in Washington was the first one after returning from overseas. At that point, at the beginning of the last leg of his huge tour, Bruce had literally conquered the world – Australia, Japan, Europe, the US. Sold out audiences in places he’d never been before.
My best guess for the top 40 part is “The battle of new Orleans” by Johnny Horton it was #1 in 1959
Yep, it’s a coincidence. I was there in the pit near the person with the sign for it, and it caught Patti’s eye. She’s the one who convinced Bruce to play it.
I believe Max was sick that evening and didn’t meet or see Bruce. His band opened and Max spent night backstage
Ken, this is a great perspective. Great observations. Thank you
Interesting, I just heard it for the first time – I swear it sounds like he is vocally, lyrically and musically channeling Bob Dylan.
Here we are!
I think that it’s Howard Fineman (Newsweek writer) pictured with Tony Goldwyn.

Not for nothing, but May 6 is Julianne Philips’ birthday….

Is it a coincidence that he played it on May 6 2014 after not playing for nearly 10 yrs and not playing it since?
New for 2025: entry 2024: Bruce’s improvised cameo on “Curb Your Enthusiasm” is so fun to watch; also, loved Susie Essman’s tale of the “Bruce selfie”. (Thanks for finding and sharing.)

Hi Ken, I was lucky enough to be at the San Diego show. It was the first time since 1981 that he and the ESB had been here. He played a solo acoustic show here in 1996. He mentioned the 1981 show during the concert, and it was also reported that way in the San Diego Union-Tribune. (You mentioned that it had been 18 years since they had played here.) I sure do appreciate your newsletter–I read it daily. Thanks for your efforts.

Great piece as always, Ken. The only thing I disagree on: I would absolutely request this song. Unfortunately I’d have to be as persistent as that guy who chased him all over Europe before having his request for Take ‘Em as They Come fulfilled! Thanks for all you do.
These are fantastic—who kept such meticulous notes of Bruce’s journey….did he?

“Behind him, the E Street Band was tuning up with some improvised jazz licks. Sprinsteen’s guitar dangled at his waist, then suddenly out of the band’s cacophony materializes ‘Night’.”
Love this image from William Haine’s 3.26.76 Atlantic Journal and Constitution show review.
Thanks for the kind words, Charlie. The link may not be in the email digest version, if that’s where you were looking, but it should be visible as a soundcloud link if you come directly to the site.
Hi there! I am probably just missing the link but I can’t seem to find the Arizona interview? This blog is incredible – thank you!
Was lucky enough to see all 5 shows in Sydney in 1985 and record them. Fantastic memories. He played over 40 songs during the five show run.

Great piece, Ken. I’d never heard that first London arrangement, but it’s absolutely my new favorite. For what it’s worth, I had an additional thought about Bruce dropping that final verse. Those lyrics sort of remind me of the final verse of Magic (“Now there’s a fire down below, and it’s coming up here.”) As you mentioned, without that final verse, Long Walk Home leaves us with some hope. Magic is a very dark song and leaves us with none – “This is what will be.”. The two work very well together that way. It was indeed a bleak time (and here we are again in 2025); still at the end of every hard-earned day…
Ken – how do I upload a newspaper article to you?

“A Springsteen Look at NCAA Tournament”: In his unusual look at the upcoming 2000 NCAA hoops tourney, article writer John Erfort’s predicted winner of Michigan State was correct as the Spartans defeated the Florida Gators 89-76 in the finals.
Who the hell is RAY BENNETT???

New for 2025: Video for 2012
“There is film of it. I’d like to see what the story on that (is) sometime…might be fun to see that someday.”–Bruce speaking with E Street Radio. Enjoyed the live footage from The Apollo of “We Take Care of Our Own”, “Wrecking Ball” and “Death to My Hometown”. Thanks for including.
